author: Redacci√≥n El Pa√≠s
title: Este es el tipo de arrugas que nunca desaparecen del rostro
text: Belleza Este es el tipo de arrugas que nunca desaparecen del rostro Las arrugas son probablemente una de las principales preocupaciones est√©ticas de muchas mujeres y hombres a partir de los 30 √≥ 40 a√±os de edad. [Por: Redacci√≥n El Pa√≠s](/autor/redaccion-el-pais/) Las arrugas son un signo natural del envejecimiento, pero no todas son iguales. Existen diferentes tipos de arrugas, cada una con sus caracter√≠sticas y causas espec√≠ficas. Adem√°s, es importante distinguir entre arrugas y l√≠neas de expresi√≥n, ya que aunque est√°n relacionadas, no son lo mismo. Tipos de arrugas - Arrugas est√°ticas: [Las arrugas est√°ticas son aquellas que se mantienen visibles en el rostro incluso cuando el rostro est√° en reposo.](https://www.elpais.com.co/belleza/vitamina-c-vs-retinol-cual-es-mejor-para-eliminar-las-arrugas-de-la-frente-1715.html) Se desarrollan con el tiempo debido a la p√©rdida de col√°geno, elastina y √°cido hialur√≥nico en la piel, lo que resulta en una disminuci√≥n de la firmeza y elasticidad. - Causas: La exposici√≥n al sol, el tabaquismo, la deshidrataci√≥n, y el proceso natural de envejecimiento son factores clave en su aparici√≥n. - Tratamiento: Los tratamientos m√°s efectivos para las arrugas est√°ticas incluyen el uso de productos antienvejecimiento con retinoides, antioxidantes, y √°cido hialur√≥nico. Adem√°s, los tratamientos dermatol√≥gicos como el l√°ser, los peelings qu√≠micos y los rellenos d√©rmicos pueden ayudar a reducir su apariencia. - Arrugas din√°micas: Estas arrugas se forman debido a la repetici√≥n de movimientos faciales, como sonre√≠r, fruncir el ce√±o o levantar las cejas. Al principio, solo son visibles cuando se realiza el gesto, pero con el tiempo pueden convertirse en arrugas est√°ticas. - Causas: Las arrugas din√°micas son principalmente el resultado de la contracci√≥n repetitiva de los m√∫sculos faciales. - Tratamiento: El uso de toxina botul√≠nica (botox) es uno de los tratamientos m√°s efectivos para las arrugas din√°micas. Este tratamiento relaja temporalmente los m√∫sculos responsables de las arrugas, suavizando su apariencia. Tambi√©n se recomienda el uso de cremas hidratantes y productos que promuevan la producci√≥n de col√°geno. - Arrugas gravitacionales: Estas arrugas se desarrollan debido a la gravedad que, con el tiempo, tira de la piel hacia abajo, especialmente en √°reas como las mejillas, la mand√≠bula y el cuello. - Causas: La p√©rdida de volumen en la piel y la falta de elasticidad contribuyen a la formaci√≥n de arrugas gravitacionales. - Tratamiento: Los tratamientos para este tipo de arrugas incluyen el uso de rellenos d√©rmicos, que ayudan a reponer el volumen perdido, y tratamientos de estiramiento de la piel, como los hilos tensores o la cirug√≠a est√©tica. - Arrugas por deshidrataci√≥n: Estas arrugas se deben a la falta de hidrataci√≥n en la piel. Son m√°s superficiales y suelen aparecer en la frente, alrededor de los ojos y en otras √°reas donde la piel es m√°s fina. - Causas: La exposici√≥n a climas secos, la falta de ingesta adecuada de agua y el uso de productos que resecan la piel son las principales causas de estas arrugas. - Tratamiento: La hidrataci√≥n es clave para tratar este tipo de arrugas. El uso de cremas y s√©rums con √°cido hialur√≥nico, que atrae y retiene la humedad en la piel, junto con una ingesta adecuada de agua, puede mejorar significativamente su apariencia. - Arrugas de compresi√≥n: [Estas arrugas se desarrollan debido a la posici√≥n en la que se duerme, generalmente aparecen en las mejillas y en la frente.](https://www.elpais.com.co/belleza/la-vitamina-esencial-que-debe-agregar-en-la-crema-de-noche-ayuda-a-eliminar-las-arrugas-para-lucir-de-40-a-los-60-0554.html) Con el tiempo, la repetici√≥n de estas posturas puede hacer que las arrugas se vuelvan permanentes. - Causas: La presi√≥n constante sobre la piel durante el sue√±o es la principal causa de estas arrugas. - Tratamiento: Cambiar la posici√≥n para dormir y usar fundas de almohada de seda puede ayudar a reducir su aparici√≥n. Tambi√©n es recomendable el uso de productos antienvejecimiento que mejoren la elasticidad de la piel. Diferencias entre arrugas y l√≠neas de expresi√≥n Las l√≠neas de expresi√≥n son pliegues que aparecen en la piel debido a los movimientos repetitivos de los m√∫sculos faciales, como sonre√≠r, fruncir el ce√±o o levantar las cejas. Al principio, estas l√≠neas solo son visibles cuando el rostro est√° en movimiento, pero con el tiempo, pueden convertirse en arrugas din√°micas si no se toman medidas preventivas. La principal diferencia entre las arrugas y las l√≠neas de expresi√≥n radica en su origen y permanencia. Mientras que las l√≠neas de expresi√≥n son temporales y solo aparecen con el movimiento, las arrugas, especialmente las est√°ticas, son permanentes y est√°n presentes incluso cuando el rostro est√° en reposo. Prevenci√≥n y tratamiento Para prevenir y tratar tanto las arrugas como las l√≠neas de expresi√≥n, es importante adoptar una rutina de cuidado de la piel que incluya la limpieza diaria, el uso de protector solar, y la aplicaci√≥n de productos que promuevan la regeneraci√≥n celular y la producci√≥n de col√°geno. [Los tratamientos dermatol√≥gicos, como el botox, los rellenos d√©rmicos, y los procedimientos l√°ser, tambi√©n pueden ser eficaces.](https://www.elpais.com.co/belleza/como-prevenir-la-aparicion-de-arrugas-antes-de-los-30-1334.html) *Este art√≠culo fue creado con ayuda de una inteligencia artificial que utiliza machine learning para producir texto similar al humano, y curado por un periodista especializado de El Pa√≠s. Reg√≠strate gratis a nuestro bolet√≠n de noticias Recibe todos los d√≠as en tu correo electr√≥nico contenido relevante para iniciar la jornada. ¬°Hazlo ahora y mantente al d√≠a con la mejor informaci√≥n digital!

author: Aiko Gao Ishida
title: Tenable warns of rising cloud risks in Singapore, Southeast Asia
text:
A report released by cybersecurity firm Tenable on June 19, 2025, highlights major cloud security risks in Singapore and Southeast Asia.
The ‚Äú2025 Cloud Security Risk Report‚Äù reveals issues like misconfigured storage systems and embedded secrets in workloads, which may lead to data breaches and regulatory violations.
It found that 9% of cloud storage resources contain sensitive data, and nearly 10% of publicly accessible storage has confidential information due to weak access controls.
The report also shows that 54% of organizations using AWS ECS task definitions have embedded secrets, creating risks of cloud environment takeovers.
Additionally, 3.5% of AWS EC2 instances have embedded credentials, increasing the threat of privilege escalation.
Ari Eitan, Tenable‚Äôs director of Cloud Security Research, warned, ‚ÄúComplacency is costly.‚Äù He stressed the need to protect sensitive data and credentials.
üîó Source: Tenable
üß† Food for thought 1Ô∏è‚É£ Southeast Asia‚Äôs data breach history highlights the urgency of cloud security The cloud vulnerabilities identified by Tenable aren‚Äôt theoretical concerns, as they reflect persistent security issues that have already resulted in significant breaches across the region.
In 2019, Sephora suffered a major breach exposing personal data of customers across Singapore, Malaysia, Indonesia, Thailand, the Philippines, Hong Kong, Australia, and New Zealand, including names, birth dates, and encrypted passwords 1 .
That same year, Malindo Air disclosed a breach affecting approximately 30 million passengers when former employees of an Indian contractor improperly accessed sensitive data, including passport numbers, home addresses, and phone numbers 2 .
These historical incidents demonstrate the very real consequences of cloud security vulnerabilities in Southeast Asia, particularly the risks associated with third-party contractors and misconfigured access controls, which align with the issues highlighted in Tenable‚Äôs findings.
The region‚Äôs growing digitalization has only increased the attack surface, with cybersecurity firm Palo Alto Networks reporting a nearly fivefold increase in daily cloud-based security alerts by the end of 2024, including a 235% increase in high-severity alerts targeting identity access management tokens 3 .
2Ô∏è‚É£ Southeast Asia‚Äôs evolving regulatory landscape creates complex compliance challenges Tenable‚Äôs findings on cloud vulnerabilities are particularly concerning given the increasingly stringent and diverse data protection regulations across Southeast Asia.
Indonesia‚Äôs Personal Data Protection Law enacted in 2022 now imposes penalties of up to 2% of annual revenue for non-compliance, while Malaysia‚Äôs PDPA amendments require organizations to appoint data protection officers and notify authorities of breaches, with fines reaching 1 million ringgit 4 .
Singapore‚Äôs robust regulatory framework under the PDPA and Cybersecurity Act emphasizes consent and accountability for data handling, with penalties up to S$1 million, creating a high compliance bar for businesses operating in the region 4 .
The implementation of Thailand‚Äôs PDPA in 2022 added another layer of complexity by requiring consent for sensitive data processing and introducing penalties including both fines and potential imprisonment 4 .
This regulatory patchwork means that the cloud vulnerabilities identified by Tenable, particularly the 9% of storage resources containing sensitive data and the 54% of organizations with embedded secrets, represent not just security risks but significant compliance and financial liabilities across multiple jurisdictions.
3Ô∏è‚É£ Cloud security emerges as a competitive differentiator in Southeast Asia‚Äôs digital infrastructure race Tenable‚Äôs findings come at a crucial juncture as Southeast Asia emerges as a key battleground for cloud computing infrastructure and services.
Billions of dollars are being invested in building digital infrastructure across the region, with countries like Singapore and Indonesia leading in digital transformation efforts that rely heavily on secure cloud environments 5 .
The region has become a strategic focus in the competition between U.S. and Chinese cloud service providers, elevating the importance of security as a key differentiator in winning market share 5 .
As Southeast Asian nations develop their digital economies, robust cybersecurity practices are becoming essential for fostering trust in cloud services, particularly given the intensifying focus of attackers on identity access management and data exfiltration identified in recent threat research 3 .
Singapore‚Äôs initiatives like the Cloud Outage Incident Response (COIR) framework mentioned in the Tenable report reflect the recognition that cloud security is not just an organizational concern but a national economic and security priority in the region‚Äôs digital transformation journey.

author: Tridivesh Singh Maini
title: Saudi Arabia-Iran deal and the turmoil in the Middle East - Modern Diplomacy
text:
On March 10 2023, Iran and Saudi Arabia agreed to resume diplomatic relations after a period of 6 years. Both countries committed to opening embassies in each other‚Äôs countries and reviving important agreements signed between both countries in the past. The agreement was brokered by China
According to a statement issued by China, Iran and Saudi Arabia,
‚Äúto resume diplomatic relations between them and reopen their embassies and missions within a period not exceeding two month,‚Äù
The agreement was significant for more than one reason:
First, it was argued by several commentators, that the agreement being brokered by China was a strong reiteration of the fact that Beijing‚Äôs influence in the Middle East had risen significantly in recent years, while US influence was waning due to China‚Äôs growing economic engagement with the Middle East.
Interestingly, Washington while being cautious of Iran honouring its commitments, pertaining to the deal, had welcomed the agreement if it helped in stabilising the Middle East ‚Äì specifically with regard to Yemen and Syria.
While commenting on the deal, White House spokesperson had said :
‚ÄúIf this deal can be sustained ‚Äî regardless of what the interest was or who sat down at the table ‚Äî if it can be sustained, and the war in Yemen can end, and Saudi Arabia doesn‚Äôt have to continually try to defend itself against attacks from the Houthis who are funded and supported by Iran, in the end we welcome that,‚Äù
Second, the agreement was important because Saudi-Iran ties had dipped significantly in 2016. In fact, the Biden Administration‚Äôs initial focus on reducing tensions with Iran and reviving the 2015 Joint Comprehensive Plan of Action, JCPOA/Iran nuclear deal was not viewed positively by Saudi Arabia.
In the aftermath of the agreement, there has been optimism regarding expansion of economic ties between both countries, though stringent US sanctions on Iran have proven to be a major impediment.
One year since the deal and turmoil in the Middle East
One year down the line, the Middle East is in turmoil. It is not just the Israel-Palestine conflict which has carried on for over 4 months, but attacks by the Houthis ‚Äî Iranian backed rebels in Yemen ‚Äî on US military bases in the Middle East, as well as on ships in the Red Sea which have impacted not just the Middle East, but had a significant global impact on the economy, since a significant percentage of global trade (between 12-15%) passes through the Red Sea. Several commercial ships have been damaged by Houthi drones or missiles since mid-November. In the most recent attack by the Houthis a Greek-owned, Barbados-flagged ship True Confidence was set ablaze in the Gulf of Aden killing three crew members. As a result of this situation, countries have begun to use the Cape of Good Hope.
It would be pertinent to point out that Gulf nations ‚Äì Saudi Arabia and UAE ‚Äî while not wanting to take on Iran have repeatedly flagged the need for alternative trade routes.
China‚Äôs role in the Middle East
In the aftermath of the Houthi attacks on the Red Sea, China has spoken to Iran to prevent further attacks by Houthis on its economic interests (there is no clarity whether Beijing only spoke to Tehran regarding its own economic interests, or also to secure economic interests of other countries).
The Chinese have also not joined a coalition of US and UK to secure the Red Sea
Republican Senator Mitt Romney while flagging China‚Äôs approach towards the Red Sea dispute
 ‚ÄúWe‚Äôre out there with our flag flying and our men and women in harm‚Äôs way. China is the nation that I would presume is most impacted by closing off trade to the Red Sea, and yet they‚Äôre sitting on the sidelines pretending like they‚Äôre everybody‚Äôs friend,‚Äù
A possible Trump Presidency and its impact on the Middle East
A Trump presidency which is highly probable will also be important because it was Trump who had pulled out of the Iran Nuclear Deal and US-Iran ties had witnessed a significant downward slope. The Biden administration has been unsuccessful in reviving the Iran Nuclear deal, attempts have been made to reduce tensions with Tehran. In fact, several Republican policy makers as well as Trump have blamed the Biden Administration‚Äôs relaxation of sanctions vis-√†-vis Iran for the Middle East conflict. A more belligerent approach by the US, under Trump, vis-√†-vis Iran could create more uncertainty in the Middle East and it remains to be seen how the Saudis, who have resumed diplomatic ties with Tehran, would react to the same.
Possible Saudi role in reducing tensions between Iran and the west
While there has been a lot of discussion about Beijing using its influence vis-√†-vis Iran, there is scope for Saudi Arabia to act as an intermediary between Iran and the west. It remains to be seen if the west uses Saudi Arabia.
In conclusion, the landscape of the Middle East has changed significantly over the past year. It remains to be seen if the improvement in ties between Tehran and Riyadh, since the past year can be utilised for introducing a modicum of stability in the region.

author: Don Chaddock, Inside CDCR editor
title: Chico parole agent saves life using Narcan - Inside CDCR
text: In April, Parole Agents Huey and Whittaker were working in Chico when they noticed two men attempting to render aid on an unconscious man. Huey took action, heading to the scene while his partner called 911. Assessing the victim, Huey thought he might need CPR, then he spotted one of the men with an empty Narcan canister. After discovering the man may have overdosed on drugs, the people who were helping at the scene told Huey they had only administered one Narcan dose. Immediately, Huey gave the man two additional doses while waiting for emergency medical services (EMS) to arrive. The agent could see the victim, while unconscious, was beginning to breathe again. Once EMS arrived and began to transport the man to the hospital, the victim regained consciousness. When asked about his experience, Huey stated said he could remain calm due to the training he received through the Department. ‚ÄúWith the ever-growing unfortunate drug addiction and drug use in our community, I am sad to say we see it frequently,‚Äù he said. Huey has been trained in Narcan use and is also a CPR/First Aid instructor. The Division of Adult Parole Operations extends appreciation and thanks to the quick actions of Agents Huey and Whittaker. Submitted by Division of Adult Parole Operations [Learn more about CDCR‚Äôs parole agents.](https://www.cdcr.ca.gov/insidecdcr/category/division-of-adult-parole-operations/) Follow CDCR on [YouTube](https://www.youtube.com/user/CACorrections/featured), [X (formerly Twitter)](https://twitter.com/cacorrections). Listen to the [CDCR Unlocked podcast](https://rss.com/podcasts/cdcrunlocked/). Related content [Southern Region parole honors Juneteenth](https://www.cdcr.ca.gov/insidecdcr/2024/06/28/southern-region-parole-honors-juneteenth/) The Business Services Unit at Southern Region parole headquarters recently organized its inaugural Juneteenth celebration. [Chico parole agent saves life using Narcan](https://www.cdcr.ca.gov/insidecdcr/2024/06/24/chico-parole-agent-saves-life-using-narcan/) In April, Parole Agents Huey and Whittaker were working in Chico when they noticed two men attempting to render aid on an unconscious man. [Parole success requires community partners](https://www.cdcr.ca.gov/insidecdcr/2024/06/13/parole-success-requires-community-partners/) For reentry success, rural parole offices like the Redding Parole Unit collaborate with community partners and other agencies. ‚Äú(We are) getting them clothed, housed, fed and meeting their basic needs so they can better focus on reentry,‚Äù said Justin Benson, Parole Agent II. [Ventura Training Center staff visits camps](https://www.cdcr.ca.gov/insidecdcr/2024/06/05/ventura-training-center-staff-visits-camps/) Ventura Training Center (VTC) staff embarked on a four-day trip through Central California to visit CDCR conservation camps and firehouses to discuss the training center‚Äôs reentry opportunities. [Meet Justin Benson, Parole Agent II](https://www.cdcr.ca.gov/insidecdcr/2024/05/24/meet-justin-benson-parole-agent-ii/) Justin Benson knows the people served by the Redding Parole Unit, mainly because he lives and works in the community as a parole agent II. For seven years, he‚Äôs been with the Division of Adult Parole Operations and previously did an 11-year stint with the Shasta County Probation Department. [DAPO raises funds for mental health](https://www.cdcr.ca.gov/insidecdcr/2024/05/22/dapo-raises-funds-for-mental-health/) During the third annual Division of Adult Parole Operations (DAPO) Be Well mental health initiative, $3,250 was raised for the National Alliance on Mental Illness (NAMI).

author: MENAFN
title: FM Of France Supports Transfer Of Proceeds From Russia's Frozen Assets To Ukraine | MENAFN.COM
text:
( MENAFN - UkrinForm) French Foreign Minister SteÃÅphane Sejourne has confirmed France's intention to help channel the proceeds of Russian assets frozen in the EU to Ukraine's defence and reconstruction.
This was reported by Ukrinform with reference to Sejourne's interview with the "Novaya Gazeta. Europe ".
"We froze Russian assets in the EU to make it more difficult for Russia to finance its illegal war. France really wants to go even further: in the face of rising interest rates, these assets generated revenues of about EUR 4 billion in 2023. We propose to use them to finance Ukraine's defence and reconstruction efforts," Sejourne said.
However, he was silent on the size of the share of frozen Russian assets that are located in France.
The foreign minister also noted that the French authorities cannot directly influence French companies such as Auchan, Leroy Merlin, Decathlon and Total to leave the Russian market. At the same time, Sejourne stressed that a large number of French companies that had been operating in Russia had already left after the start of the full-scale invasion of Ukraine.
Read also: Germany sends more than 100 humanitarian aid shipments in support of Ukraine's energy secto "The Kremlin's growing aggressiveness towards France played an important role in this. In addition, it is increasingly difficult for businesses to be in a situation where they are associated with a regime that has become so marginalised internationally and is condemned by almost all countries in the world. In order to regain its place in the community of nations, Russia must make a different choice," Sejourne said.
As Ukrinform previously reported, in mid-April, G7 finance ministers reaffirmed their support for Ukraine and their intention to use frozen Russian assets for it.

author: New York Times
title: Israel‚Äôs Military Defends Strike on U.N. School Building, Saying Its Target Was 30 Militants
text:
Facing international criticism of its conduct of the war and its latest strike a U.N. school building being used as a shelter in Nuseirat, the Israeli military offered a full-throated defense of the operation, insisting its forces had targeted a group of about 30 militants using three classrooms as a base.
A military spokesman, Rear Adm. Daniel Hagari, said Israel had carried out ‚Äúa precise, intelligence-based strike‚Äù against ‚Äúdozens of Hamas and Islamic Jihad terrorists hiding inside a U.N. school.‚Äù He said some of the militants had participated in the attacks against Israel on Oct. 7.
Admiral Hagari said the operation took place after ‚Äúthree days of surveillance‚Äù and was designed to destroy three specific classrooms in the school where the Israeli military believed roughly 30 militants were staying and planning operations.
Israel twice delayed the strike on the school complex because it had identified civilians in the area, he said.
‚ÄúThe terrorists inside the school were planning more attacks against Israelis, some of them imminent,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúWe stopped a ticking time bomb.‚Äù
Gazan health officials say at least 40 people were killed in the strike, including women and children.
To support its contention the strike was on a military target, the Israeli military released the names of nine people killed in the attack that it said were associated with Hamas and Islamic Jihad. Two of those named were associated with Hamas and seven with Islamic Jihad, according to the Israeli military. Admiral Hagari said the military is working on identifying others.
It is a crime under international law to intentionally target civilians who are not participating in the hostilities, but the rules do allow for ‚Äúincidental‚Äù and ‚Äúinvoluntary‚Äù damage ‚Äî including civilian deaths ‚Äî if they are deemed proportional, meaning that incidental damage can‚Äôt be excessive compared to the military advantage gained. It is a somewhat ambiguous standard that is open to interpretation, however, experts say.
The United Nations human rights office said in a statement that the Israeli strike in Nuseirat ‚Äúsuggests a failure‚Äù by the military to ‚Äúensure strict compliance with international humanitarian law, particularly the basic principles of distinction, proportionality and precaution in attack.‚Äù The office added that even if armed Palestinians were using the school as a base of operations, as Israel claims, it would not ‚Äújustify violations of these principles.‚Äù
Admiral Hagari said Israeli forces had complied with international law in carrying out the strike and accused some media outlets of falling for Hamas propaganda.
Reprising an argument Israel has used throughout the war, Admiral Hagari accused Hamas of embedding its fighters among civilians and using them as shields. He said the militant‚Äôs strategy of hiding inside U.N. facilities was itself a war crime.
‚ÄúHamas wages war from schools and hospitals,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúHamas hopes the international law and public sympathy will provide a shield for their military activities, which is why they systematically operate from schools, U.N. facilities, hospitals, and mosques.
John F. Kirby, the United States National Security Council coordinator, in an interview on CNN on Thursday, said that Israel ‚Äúabsolutely‚Äù has a right to target Hamas and that it is known that its fighters ‚Äúshelter in civilian facilities,‚Äù but noted that this does not give Israel carte blanche. He said that the U.S. is discussing the incident with Israeli authorities and has not independently verified what happened. ‚ÄúWe are asking for more information, more context,‚Äù Mr. Kirby said.
The post
 Israel‚Äôs Military Defends Strike on U.N. School Building, Saying Its Target Was 30 Militants appeared first on New York Times.

author: @dailystarnews
title: New building of Lalmonirhat hospital lies unused amid manpower shortage
text:
Hospitals Hospitals New building of Lalmonirhat hospital lies unused Thu Dec 19, 2024 07:47 PM
Last update on: Thu Dec 19, 2024 08:28 PM
S Dilip Roy Thu Dec 19, 2024 07:47 PM Last update on: Thu Dec 19, 2024 08:28 PM
Although the construction of an eight-storey building for Lalmonirhat Sadar Hospital was completed in April this year, it remains unused due to a severe manpower shortage.
As a result, despite the hospital's official upgrade to a 250-bed facility, its operational capacity remains limited to that of a 100-bed hospital.
For all latest news, follow The Daily Star's Google News channel. During a recent visit, this correspondent observed patients being treated in the old building, many forced to lie on the floor due to a lack of available beds, enduring immense suffering in extreme cold.
The shortage of doctors, nurses, and staff was also evident compared to the number of admitted patients.
"My three-year-old son, suffering from cold-related complications, is being treated on the cold floor due to the lack of beds, worsening his condition," said Sabina Begum, 25, of Kulaghat village.
"If the new building was in use, it could have accommodated more patients and prevented such suffering," she added.
Kader Mia, 50, of Sarpukur village, echoed her concerns. His 75-year-old father, battling respiratory issues, is also being treated on the floor.
"My father's recovery is slow due to the lack of proper care. Although medicines are available, nurses aren't providing adequate attention," he said.
Sekender Ali, 45, of Shaheed Shahjahan Colony area in Lalmonirhat town, said the old building's premises are dirty and malodorous, leaving patients compelled to withstand the stench while undergoing treatment.
He urged the hospital authorities to initiate treatment in the new building for patients' welfare.
According to hospital sources, the hospital has adequate food and medical supplies for 250 patients, but the manpower is hardly enough to provide treatment to 100 patients at once.
At present, only outdoor services have been opened in the new hospital building, while all other services are still being provided in the old building due to manpower shortage.
Contacted, Dr Abdul Mokaddem, superintendent of the hospital, said the hospital currently has only 19 doctors and 62 nurses, while it needs at least 90 doctors and 160 nurses to function properly as a 250-bed hospital. In addition, 24 other staff posts are also lying vacant, he added.
"If we start providing services in the new building, the number of patients will increase, but the available manpower will be insufficient to deliver services properly. At present, we are struggling to provide treatment to patients in 100 beds in the old building," he said.
"If more doctors, nurses, and staff are appointed, we will be able to conduct medical services in the new building, which will in turn benefit the patients. A letter has been sent to the relevant higher authorities in this regard," he added.
Click to comment Comments Comments Policy

author: Yohan Demeure, expert g√©ographe
title: Des √©tudiantes ont mis au point une technologie pour limiter certains accidents de la route
text:
Aux √âtats-Unis, un groupe d‚Äô√©tudiantes a √©labor√© un dispositif en th√©orie capable de sauver des vies humaines et animales sur les routes isol√©es. Il est en effet question d‚Äôune sorte de d√©tecteur qui d√©clenche un avertisseur sonore lorsqu‚Äôun animal sauvage est sur le point de traverser la route.
Un dispositif fonctionnant sur les cerfs Le Colorado (√âtats-Unis) est enti√®rement situ√© √† une altitude d√©passant les mille m√®tres . Les Grandes Plaines occupent l‚Äôest du territoire tandis que les montagnes Rocheuses et le plateau du Colorado se trouvent dans la partie ouest, ce qui conf√®re √† cet √âtat des paysages exceptionnels.
